facts.text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated March 20, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated March 20, 1969 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Election Petition No. 1 of 1968.

facts.text: Kundan Singh, the 1st respondent, challenged the validity of the returning officer's declaration that the appellant was duly elected from the Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency to the Punjab Legislative Council in the election held in April 1968.

anchor.surface_text: In that election petition, Kundan Singh, the 1st respondent to this appeal challenged the validity of the returning officers declaration that the appellant has been duly elected from the Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency to the Punjab Legislative Council in the election held in April, 1968.

facts.text: Election calendar for Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency: last date for filing nomination papers 12-3-1968, scrutiny 13-3-1968, withdrawal 16-3-1968, polling 7-4-1968, counting and declaration 8-4-1968.

anchor.surface_text: The election calendar was as follows The last date for filing numberination papers --12-3-1968. Date of scrutiny of the numberination papers 13-3-1968. The last date for withdrawal of candidatures 16-3-1968. Date of polling-- 7-4-1968. Date of companynting and declaration of result 8-4-1968.

facts.text: On April 8, 1968, returning officer declared appellant successful candidate as he secured one vote more than 1st respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On April 8, 1968, the returning officer after companynting the votes cast declared the appellant to be the successful candidate as he had secured one vote more than the 1st respondent.

facts.text: 1st respondent challenged vote of Hari Singh as void because his name included in electoral roll on April 5, 1968, two days before polling.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent challenged that declaration in the aforementioned election petition on various grounds of which, at present, we are only companycerned with one viz. that the vote of Hari Singh should have been held to be a void vote as his name was included in the electoral roll on April 5, 1968 i.e. just two days before the date of polling.

facts.text: Appellant filed recriminatory petition contending vote of Tarsem Singh void as he became government servant by polling time.

anchor.surface_text: In his. turn the appellant filed a recriminatory petition companytending inter alia that the vote of Tarsem Singh was void as by the time the polling took place, he had become a government servant

facts.text: Appellant contended votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh void as their names included in electoral roll after last date for nominations.

anchor.surface_text: and the votes of two. other persons namely Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh were void as their names were included in the electoral roll after the last date for filing numberinations for the election.

facts.text: High Court Full Bench held vote of Hari Singh void as name included after last date for nominations.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench by majority came to. the companyclusion that the vote of Hari Singh was void as his name was included in the electoral roll of the companystituency after the last date for making numberinations for the election in that companystituency.

facts.text: Trial judge held votes of Hari Singh, Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh void, recounted valid votes, declared 1st respondent duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the opinion expressed by the Full Bench, the learned judge came to the companyclusion that the votes of Hari Singh, Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh were void votes. Consequently he recounted the votes validly cast and came to the companyclusion that the 1 st respondent had been duly elected.

facts.text: Five candidates contested the election: appellant and respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In that election, as many as five candidates companytested. They are the appellant and the respondents herein.

facts.text: Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency called to elect one member to Punjab Legislative Council in March 1968.

anchor.surface_text: We may number briefly state the material facts. In March 1968, the Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency was called upon to elect one member to the Punjab Legislative Council.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal against High Court decision in Election Petition No.1 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal under s. 116A of the Representation of People Act, 1951  to be shortly referred to hereinafter as the Act  is directed against the decision of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana in Election Petition No. 1 of 1968 on its file.

facts.text: Election petition tried before Mahajan J., who referred question on Hari Singh's vote to Full Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The election petition came up for trial before Mahajan, The learned judge submitted the following question to a Full Bench for decision Whether allegation in para 4 a  pertaining to the vote of Hari Singh is companyrect and the vote was void and was polled in favour of respondent No. 1 in violation of the Rules and has. materially affected the result of the election of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh votes rejected because names included after nomination date per s.23(3) 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh have been rejected on the ground that their names were included in the electoral roll in defiance of the mandate given under s. 23  3  of the 1950 Act.

facts.text: Tarsem Singh's name in electoral roll but appellant claimed disqualified as government servant after inclusion.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that Tarsem Singhs name finds place in the electoral roll of the companystituency but the argument was that as he had taken up government service subsequent to the inclusion of his name in the electoral roll, he became disqualified

facts.text: Supreme Court held votes of Hari Singh, Harjinder Singh, Balwant Singh void under s.23(3) of 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: What applies to. Hari Singh equally applies to Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh. The fact that the 1st respondent did number challenge the validity of those votes is immaterial in the circumstances of this case.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected contention that Tarsem Singh's vote invalid due to becoming government servant.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention cannot be upheld. Section 62 of the Act provides thus 62 1 . No person who is number, and except as expressly provided by this Act, every person who is, for the time being entered in the electoral roll of any companystituency shall be entitled to vote in that companystituency.

facts.text: Appellant mistakenly thought Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh voted against him.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently under an erroneous impression that Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh had voted against him, the appellant had companytended in his recriminatory petition that their votes were invalid.

facts.text: One of Harjinder Singh or Balwant Singh gave first preference to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: But on scrutiny it was found that one of them had given his first preference to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court relied on its decision in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto for interpretation of s.23(3) 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have companysidered the scope of that provision in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto and Ors.  1  in  1  1970 1 S.C.R. 839. L15 Sup. CI/69--10 which we have delivered judgment just number.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the main contention in this appeal relates to the true effect of sub-s.  3   of s. 23 of the Representation of People Act, 1950  to be hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act  which prohibits the deletion of any entry or inclusion of any name in the electoral roll of a constituency after the last date for making nominations for an election in that constituency and before the completion of that election.

anchor.surface_text: Part III of the 1950 Act deals with the preparation of rolls in a constituency. The provisions contained therein prescribe the qualifications for being registered as a voter  S. 19 , disqualifications which disentitle a person from being registered as a voter  S. 16 , revision of the rolls  s. 21 , correction of entries in the electoral rolls  s. 22 , inclusion of the names in the electoral rolls  S. 23 , appeals against orders passed by the concerned authorities under ss. 22 and 23  S. 24 . Sections 14 to 24 of the 1950 Act are integrated provisions.

concepts.interpretation: Form complete code for preparation and maintenance of electoral rolls; entries final, not challengeable in election validity proceedings

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the main contention in this appeal relates to the true effect of sub-s.  3   of s. 23 of the Representation of People Act, 1950  to be hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act  which prohibits the deletion of any entry or inclusion of any name in the electoral roll of a constituency after the last date for making nominations for an election in that constituency and before the completion of that election.

arguments.claim: s.23(3) of 1950 Act prohibits deletion or inclusion in electoral roll after last nomination date until completion of election; applies to Hari Singh etc., rendering votes void.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the main contention in this appeal relates to the true effect of sub-s.  3   of s. 23 of the Representation of People Act, 1950  to be hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act  which prohibits the deletion of any entry or inclusion of any name in the electoral roll of a constituency after the last date for making nominations for an election in that constituency and before the completion of that election.

arguments.claim: View of Full Bench on s.23(3) correct as per scope considered in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto.

anchor.surface_text: We have considered the scope of that provision in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto and Ors.  1  in  1  1970 1 S.C.R. 839. L15 Sup. CI/69--10 which we have delivered judgment just now. In view of that decision, the view taken by the majority of the Full Bench must be held to be correct.

arguments.claim: Validity of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh votes excluded as part of same enquiry despite not challenged by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: What applies to Hari Singh equally applies to Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh. The fact that the 1st respondent did not challenge the validity of those votes is immaterial in the circumstances of this case. The election petition and the recriminatory petition were parts of one enquiry.

arguments.claim: Tarsem Singh entitled to vote as name in electoral roll; becoming government servant after inclusion does not disqualify under Act.

anchor.surface_text: This contention cannot be upheld. Section 62 of the Act provides thus 62 1 . No person who is not, and except as expressly provided by this Act, every person who is, for the time being entered in the electoral roll of any constituency shall be entitled to vote in that constituency.

arguments.claim: Electoral roll entries final; not challengeable in election validity proceedings or civil courts per ss.14-24,30 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 30 of the 1950 Act, civil courts have no jurisdiction... It is clear from those provisions that the entries found in the electoral roll are final and they are not open to challenge either before a civil court or before a tribunal which considers the validity of any election.

arguments.claim: Right to vote purely statutory; validity examined only under Act provisions, not outside.

anchor.surface_text: The right to vote being purely a statutory right, the validity of any vote has to be examined on the basis of the provisions of the Act. We cannot travel outside those provisions to find out whether a particular vote was a valid vote or not.

holdings.text: In view of that decision, the view taken by the majority of the Full Bench must be held to be correct.

anchor.surface_text: We have considered the scope of that provision in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto and Ors.  1  in  1  1970 1 S.C.R. 839. L15 Sup. CI/69--10 which we have delivered judgment just now. In view of that decision, the view taken by the majority of the Full Bench must be held to be correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court's own recent judgment in Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto interpreting s.23(3) of 1950 Act to render votes void if name included after last nomination date.

holdings.text: What applies to Hari Singh equally applies to Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh. The fact that the 1st respondent did not challenge the validity of those votes is immaterial in the circumstances of this case. The election petition and the recriminatory petition were parts of one enquiry. As the validity of these three votes had come up for consideration and as it has been held that those votes are void votes, it necessarily follows that those votes must be excluded from consideration in determining the result of the election.

anchor.surface_text: What applies to. Hari Singh equally applies to Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh. The fact that the 1st respondent did number challenge the validity of those votes is immaterial in the circumstances of this case. The election petition and the recriminatory petition were parts of one enquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election petition and recriminatory petition form single enquiry; validity of void votes under s.23(3) considered regardless of which party challenged.

holdings.text: The mandate of that provision is plain and unambiguous. It prohibits inclusion of any name in the electoral roll after the prescribed date whether the application for inclusion was made before or after that date.

anchor.surface_text: The mandate of that provision is plain and unambiguous. It prohibits inclusion of any name in the electoral roll after the prescribed date whether the application for inclusion was made before or after that date. The ratio of that decision has no application to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.23(3); distinguishes pre-amendment Patna High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: This contention cannot be upheld. Section 62 of the Act provides thus 62 1 . No person who is number, and except as expressly provided by this Act, every person who is, for the time being entered in the electoral roll of any constituency shall be entitled to vote in that constituency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.62 ROPA 1951 entitles persons in electoral roll unless expressly disqualified under Act; s.16 1950 Act disqualifications inapplicable to Tarsem Singh becoming government servant post-inclusion.

holdings.text: It is clear from those provisions that the entries found in the electoral roll are final and they are not open to challenge either before a civil court or before a tribunal which considers the validity of any election.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from those provisions that the entries found in the electoral roll are final and they are not open to challenge either before a civil court or before a tribunal which considers the validity of any election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.14-24 and s.30 of 1950 Act form complete code for electoral rolls; entries conclusive; follows M. Ramaswamy v. B.M. Krishnamurthy.

holdings.text: The right to vote being purely a statutory right, the validity of any vote has to be examined on the basis of the provisions of the Act. We cannot travel outside those provisions to find out whether a particular vote was a valid vote or not.

anchor.surface_text: The right to vote being purely a statutory right, the validity of any vote has to be examined on the basis of the provisions of the Act. We cannot travel outside those provisions to find out whether a particular vote was a valid vote or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vote validity strictly per statutory provisions; no external grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The mandate of that provision is plain and unambiguous. It prohibits inclusion of any name in the electoral roll after the prescribed date whether the application for inclusion was made before or after that date. The ratio of that decision has no application to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The right to vote being purely a statutory right, the validity of any vote has to be examined on the basis of the provisions of the Act. We cannot travel outside those provisions to find out whether a particular vote was a valid vote or not.

In view of that decision, the view taken by the majority of the Full Bench must be held to be correct. Evidently under an erroneous impression that Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh had voted against him, the appellant had contended in his
